text: In this 6 Minute English, we're celebrating the life of one of modern South Africa's founding
fathers, the icon and Nobel laureate at Bishop Desmond Tutsu. Archbishop Tutsu was one of the
leaders of the non-violent movement to end the system of racial segregation known as apartheid.
apartheid was enforced against the black population of South Africa by the white minority
government from 1948 until 1991. It's impossible to imagine South Africa's difficult journey to
freedom without Archbishop Desmond Tutsu. While other anti-apartheid leaders, like his close friend
Nelson Mandela, were imprisoned or even killed, Archbishop Tutsu was there at every step of the
struggle. The rebellious priest speaking out against the injustices of apartheid. Archbishop Tutsu
was a hero of the 20th century. He died in December 2021 and was laid to rest in Cape Town in a state
funeral on New Year's Day. In this programme, we'll hear about some important moments from his life
and, as usual, learn some related vocabulary as well. But first, I have a question for you, Neil.
